[[open source]] internet suite based on the [[Mozilla Application Suite]] (MAS) by Ben Bucksch, a German [[Mozilla]] developer,<ref name="heise">{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Mozilla-Entwickler-mit-eigener-Browser-Distribution-27527.html|title=Mozilla-Entwickler mit eigener Browser-Distribution|date=14 November 2000|language=German|accessdate=29 January 2011|publisher=[[Heinz Heise]]}}</ref> which have a higher security and privacy level than other commercial products.<ref>{{cite journal|publisher=[[LinuxUser]]|url=https://www.linux-user.de/ausgabe/2001/02/007-software/software-02.html?print=y|language=German|accessdate=1 February 2011|year=2001|month=February|title=Frische Ware|first=Andreas|last=Huchler}}</ref><ref name="kefk" /><ref name="pcm">{{cite journal|journal=Personal Computer Magazine|accessdate=7 March 2011|language=Dutch|month=February|year=2004|pages=96, 97|title=Alternative Browsers|first=Peter|last=D'Hollander|issn=0772-8077}}</ref>
The internet suite contained a [[web browser]], an [[email client|email]] and [[Newsreader (Usenet)|news client]], a [[HTML editor]] (based on [[Mozilla Composer]]) and an [[Internet Relay Chat|IRC]] client (based on [[ChatZilla]]).<ref name="kefk">{{cite web|url=http://kefk.net/Open_Source/FS/Beonex/index.html|title=Beonex|accessdate=1 February 2011|date=4 June 2002|publisher=[[Kefk Network]]}}</ref><ref name="pcm" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.useragentstring.com/pages/Beonex/|accessdate=1 February 2011|title=Beonex User Agent Strings|publisher=UserAgentString.Com}}</ref>
Beonex Business Services offered the suite for free, provide documentation, easy install routines for third-party [[Plug-in (computing)|plug-ins]], and tried to sell support and customers-specific changes on the browser.<ref name="blindschleiche">{{cite web|language=German|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20041016061010/http://www.blindschleiche.de/shownews.php3/258|url=http://www.blindschleiche.de/shownews.php3/258|archivedate=16 October 2004|title=Vielversprechender Netscape 6 Konkurrent|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=26 November 2000|publisher=Blindschleiche.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computeruser.com/articles/just-browsing-thanks.html|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=30 November 2003|title=Just browsing, thanks|first=Eric|publisher=[[IDG]]|work=[[ComputerUser]]|last=Foster-Johnson}}</ref> The main goal was to implement [[Kerberos (protocol)|Kerberos]], [[OpenPGP]], and [[LDAP]] in Beonex,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mozillazine.org/talkback.html?article=1745|accessdate=29 January 2011|work=[[Mozillazine]]|publisher=[[Mozilla]]|title=Announcing Beonex|date=29 November 2000}}</ref> but that was marked as failed in mid 2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=124026|title=Bug 124026 - Roaming - funding via Beonex|publisher=Mozilla|date=24 May 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
==History== {{quote box|width = 200px|Overall, this project seems most interested in staying as true to Mozilla as possible.<ref>{{cite web|archivedate=14 November 2002| archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20021114125904/http://linuxberg.surfnet.nl/x11html/preview/154164.html|url=http://linuxberg.surfnet.nl/x11html/preview/154164.html|title=Beonex Communicator 0.6 Pre|publisher=[[Tucows]]|date=30 November 2000}}</ref>}} The [[Mozilla Organization]] stated that the Mozilla Application Suite was only for developers and testing purposes and was not meant for end users.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cybersecurity.ru/net/40269.html|title=CyberSecurity.ru | ÑÐµÑ Ð½Ð¾Ð»Ð¾Ð³Ð¸Ð¸ | Mozilla Ð¿ÑÐ°Ð·Ð´Ð½ÑÐµÑ 10-Ð»ÐµÑÐ¸Ðµ|date=23 January 2008|publisher=CyberSecurity.ru|language=Russian|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="holger">{{cite web|title=Ãber Mozilla|url=http://www.holgermetzger.de/faqabout.html|accessdate=30 January 2011|first=Holger|last=Metzger|language=German}}; shorten English version available [http://www.holgermetzger.de/eabout.html here]</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Zahmes Monster|accessdate=7 February 2011|year=2002|language=German|volume=13|page=218|magazine=[[C't]]|publisher=Heinz Heise|first=Karsten|last=Violka}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Surfen ohne e - Mit Opera und Mozilla sicherer ins Netz|accessdate=7 February 2011|year=2002|language=German|volume=25|page=106|magazine=[[C't]]|publisher=Heinz Heise|first=Jo|last=Bager}}</ref>
On the 5 January 2001 Beonex was included in the [[Linux distribution]] [[kmLinux]] version S-0.4, but was already removed in version S-0.5 released on the 23 March 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lernnetz-sh.de/kmLinux/changes.html|accessdate=1 February 2011|title=Entwicklungsgeschichte|date=6 December 2004|publisher=[[Schleswig-Holstein]]}}</ref>
Beonex 0.8 released in June 2002 received well reviews about the speed.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.linux-magazin.de/Heft-Abo/Ausgaben/2002/12/Jagdgesellschaft/(offset)|title=Jagdgesellschaft|first=Oliver|page=2|last=Kluge|year=2002|issue=12|accessdate=29 January 2011|language=German|publisher=[[Linux-Magazin]]}} {{dead link|date=September 2011}}</ref><ref name="linux community" />
[[File:BeOL.png|thumb|right|250px|a BeOL preview]] '''Beonex Launcher'''(BeOL, spoken B-O-L), was an additional upcoming product that never left [[alpha status]] which was a stripped down version of the internet suite Beonex Communicator. It was a web browser combined with an email client and a chat client.<ref>{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Bucksch|publisher=Beonex Communicator|url=http://www.developer.beonex.com/beol/|title=BeOL|accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
With a few preview releases of version 0.9 in mid 2002 he showed some new features he wanted to integrate, but before this version gained a stable status, her announced on the 2 March 2004 that no new releases were planned until the [[Mozilla Foundation]] decided its future policy.<ref>{{cite journal|publisher=[[LinuxUser]]|url=http://www.linux-magazin.de/Heft-Abo/Ausgaben/2005/09/Soll-der-Fuchs-ihn-holen|language=German|accessdate=7 February 2011|year=2005|month=September|title=Soll der Fuchs ihn holen|first=Oliver|last=Kluge|volume=9}}</ref> In 2005, the Mozilla Foundation officially changed its policies and created the [[Mozilla Corporation]] to provide end-user support.
''Beonex Communicator 0.8.2-stable'' has several known security issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/7363|publisher=[[Security Focus]]|accessdate=29 January 2011|title=Mozilla Browser Cross Domain Violation Vulnerability|date=16 April 2003}}</ref> Beonex received never big market share.<ref name="holger" />
==Comparison with Netscape and MAS== The browser disabled referrers by default and has the possibility to create a fake referrers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Digitale Spuren - Surfer hinterlassen im Netz Spuren|language=German|url=http://www.heise.de/tp/r4/artikel/14/14052/1.html|accessdate=1 February 2011|date=31 January 2003|first=Christiane|last=Schulzki-Haddouti|publisher=Heinz Heise|work=Telepolis}}</ref> The browser deleted all [[HTTP cookie|cookies]] when the program exited and also disabled several [[JavaScript]] functions which could have served as attack vectors.<ref name="pcm" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.golem.de/0206/20223.html|title=Beonex-Browser: Mozilla 1.0 mit mehr Sicherheitsfunktionen|date=7 June 2002|publisher=Golem.de|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|publisher=[[LinuxUser]]|url=http://www.linux-community.de/Internal/Artikel/Print-Artikel/LinuxUser/2001/03/Sieben-aktuelle-Web-Browser-im-Vergleich|language=German|accessdate=8 February 2011|year=2001|month=March|volume=3|title=Tore zur WWWelt - Sieben aktuelle Web-Browser im Vergleich|first=Andreas|last=Huchler}}</ref>

===Differences to Netscape=== In contrast to Netscape, Beonex had included nearly the same features except the proprietary parts like the integrated [[Net2Phone]],<ref name="giga">{{cite web|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20021203134841/http://www.giga.de/dbout/reporter5/fullstories/nr20925.html|archivedate=3 December 2002|url=http://www.giga.de/dbout/reporter5/fullstories/nr20925.html|publisher=[[GIGA Television]]|title=Zweiter Ableger vom Mozilla|language=German|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> and the [[AOL Instant Messenger]].<ref name="giga" /> The chattool ChatZilla was integrated<ref>{{cite journal|title=World Wide Web|accessdate=7 February 2011|year=2001|language=German|volume=1|page=26|magazine=[[iX (magazine)|iX]]|publisher=Heinz Heise|first=Henning|last=Behme}}</ref> and the [[Sidebar (computing)|sidebar]] and the [[web search engine|search engines]] were other preconfigured.<ref name="heise" /><ref name="linux community">{{cite web|accessdate=29 January 2011|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20020612045509/http://www.linux-community.de/Neues/story?storyid=691|url=http://www.linux-community.de/Neues/story?storyid=691|archivedate=12 July 2002|title=Slimfast fÃ¼r Mozilla|first=Fionn|last=Behrens|2 December 2000|publisher=Linux-Community.de|language=German}}</ref> Beonex was less resources intensive than Netscape.<ref name="heise2">{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/Netscape-6-Fett-aber-schnell-Update-27315.html|title=Netscape 6: Fett, aber schnell (Update)|date=14 November 2000|language=German|accessdate=29 January 2011|publisher=[[Heinz Heise]]}}</ref>
Beonex included a migration tool to include the old profiles from [[Netscape Communicator]].<ref name="pcm" /><ref name="linux community" /><!--NS6 and MAS not?-->
===Differences to MAS=== Beonex Communicator was not a [[fork (software)|fork]] of MAS, it was a separate [[Branching (software)|branch]], so not big changes were made.<ref>{{cite web|title=We are accepting patches|url=http://www.developer.beonex.com/communicator/patches/|accessdate=30 January 2011|publisher=Beonex Communicator|first=Ben|last=Bucksch}}</ref> [[HTML email]]s and JavaScript had been turned off by default and thus displaying [[email]]s only in [[plain text]] with bold and cursive additions<ref name="pcm" /><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.heise.de/ct/hotline/Nur-Text-Mails-im-Mozilla-312910.html|title=Nur-Text-Mails im Mozilla|year=2002|language=German|volume=17|page=188|magazine=[[C't]]|publisher=Heinz Heise|first=Karsten|accessdate=7 February 2011|last=Violka<!--Author is displayed at following page: http://www.heise.de/artikel-archiv/ct/2002/17/188_kiosk-->}}</ref> which was added later in MAS 1.1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.golem.de/showhigh2.php?file=/0206/20285.html|publisher=Golem.de|language=German|accessdate=7 March 2011|date=12 June 2002|title=Mozilla 1.1 Alpha ist da}}</ref> The search engines were compatible to the [[Mycroft project]] and were located in the sidebar providing more features.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linuxjournal.com/article/5413?page=0,1|title=Browser Comparison|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=1 March 2002|first=Ralph|last=Krause|publisher=[[Linux Journal]]}}</ref>
